Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Flexible control of reward based decisions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Our brains help us to adapt quickly to variable and unpredictable circumstances. However, the neural processes that allow for this flexibility remain poorly understood. The dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC) is a part of the brain that appears to be critically important for multiple aspects of our thinking, such as attention, learning, flexibility, and even creativity, but the specific contribution it makes to these processes is unclear. This proposal seeks to understand how dACC gives rise to flexible processing. Dr. Ben Hayden, University of Rochester, will perform three experiments using single-neuron recordings in dACC of rhesus macaques performing three novel decision-making tasks. He hypothesizes that dACC computes and transmits control signals that drive behavioral switching, learning, and maintaining the decisions that have been made. These complex cognitive functions are at the root of the ability to learn and to make good decisions.

The anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) is a region implicated in several psychiatric problems that are debilitating both to patient standard-of-life and to worldwide medical expenditure and economic productivity. Notably, these include long-term depression, anxiety disorder, OCD, schizophrenia amongst many others. Therefore, progress in understanding the computations performed by the ACC to control our behavior is essential. This work will highlight not only underlying neural mechanisms but also effective strategies for promoting such abilities, therefore potentially impacting individual function within the society. Finally, the researchers will participate in the big data effort by making the data available to support other coordinated NSF efforts that aim to make use of real data in the teaching of STEM related courses and to enable participation in discovery science by those who would otherwise have no access to such data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Ben Hayden

 

The central goal of this NSF CAREER award was to understand the role of one brain region, the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (abbreviated as dACC) in flexible decision making. Artificial systems, like robots, are able to do many of the kinds of things that human minds do – evaluate and compare options, identify people’s faces, math, and so on. However, one major limitation of such systems is that they tend to be highly inflexible. When circumstances change, they either continue doing the same thing they were doing before or else they shut down. Humans and other intelligent animals, by contrast, have cognitive flexibility. That is, they have the ability to detect changing circumstances and adjust to them, and rapidly incorporate new information into their mindsets and make better decisions.

 

In this study, we recorded brain activity from single neurons while subjects performed simple laboratory tasks that required flexibility. Our central hypothesis was that something about the dACC would be critical for implementing flexibility, but we wanted to know what that was. Our first discovery was related to confirming this central hypothesis. Specifically, much research indicates that dACC plays a role, but it is unclear whether that role is monitoring what occurs or whether it actually implements the control that results from that monitoring. In other words, it is unclear whether dACC is a key site for flexibility or just one that is linked to it. Using a novel set of tasks that require flexibility, we were able to show a direct relationship between brain activity in dACC (as measured by action potentials generated by single neurons there) and control.

 

Our second discovery extended these ideas to learning. We wanted to show that the putative control signals in dACC had a role in driving behaviors. That is, we wanted to link these signals in the brain to some consequence. We showed using a learning study that requires flexible learning, that our control signals do indeed drive learning.

 

Finally, we are interested in the relationship between these ideas and self-control. Self-control is a poorly understood process and one that, at a fundamental level, requires flexibility. Specifically, it requires the ability to adaptively summon additional willpower (and we don’t really know what that is) when circumstances demand it. We found that dACC tracks the value of the reward that can be anticipated in response to resisting temptation and persisting in a self-controlled state.

 

Together, these results provide an important advance in our understanding of flexibility. They identify one brain region as a key site for flexibility in the human brain, and show some of its functions in this regard. In future work, we will provide even more complex and sophisticated contexts and provide further delineation of the role of this region.
